G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A.proposition: The amount of damages claimed, exclusive of interest and costs, does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court Department of the Trial Court, and is within the jurisdiction of the Brockton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and applicable rules.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the cause of action arose in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts, and Defendant’s facility where the incident occurred is located in Brockton.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant because Defendant owns, operates, and conducts business in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including at 75 Crescent Street, Brockton, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions giving rise to this Complaint occurred within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor or operator of land open to the public for a fee, or otherwise inviting children onto its premises, owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors, including children, from foreseeable harm.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor or operator of land open to the public for a fee, or otherwise inviting children onto its premises, owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors, including children, from foreseeable harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion focused on abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and questioning how trespassers are treated. It does not discuss land open to the public for a fee, special duties owed to child visitors, or articulate a specific duty of reasonable care toward children on such premises. While the main Mounsey decision concerns occupiers’ liability generally, this particular text does not clearly support the detailed proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor or operator of land open to the public for a fee, or otherwise inviting children onto its premises, owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors, including children, from foreseeable harm.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, which includes maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, the court’s articulation of the general premises-liability duty squarely supports the cited proposition about the duty owed to lawful visitors, including children, on the possessor’s own property. The limitation is only as to adjacent public highways, not the basic duty itself.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor or operator of land open to the public for a fee, or otherwise inviting children onto its premises, owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors, including children, from foreseeable harm.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely adopts and applies the general Massachusetts premises-liability rule that a property owner or occupier owes all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition. It expressly notes that this duty applies to invitees (such as customers of a store open to the public for shopping) and to child trespassers, and treats snow and ice hazards the same as other property hazards. Although it does not single out ‘children invited onto premises’ in a separate holding, it affirmatively relies on the broad duty to all lawful visitors, which includes children, on land open to the public for business.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745 (1984).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that schools, youth organizations, and similar entities that assume responsibility for supervising children owe a duty to use reasonable care to protect those children from reasonably foreseeable harm arising from the conduct of other children.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745 (1984).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes that when an entity undertakes responsibility for supervision and protection, it owes a duty to use reasonable care to protect against foreseeable harms caused by third parties. In discussing general tort principles, the court approvingly cites cases such as McLeod v. Grant County School Dist. (school's duty to protect student from another student at recess) and Eldredge v. Kamp Kachess Youth Serv. (group child care facility’s duty to control delinquent children). These authorities are used to illustrate the broader rule that supervisory actors (including schools and youth organizations) may be liable for failing to protect children from reasonably foreseeable harm by other children, thereby supporting the proposition by analogy and citation.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745 (1984).relevant_excerpt: Furthermore, many cases have established that liability may arise solely from the violation of an affirmative duty to act with reasonable care to prevent harm to another caused by a third person. See, e.g., Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54 (1983) (college has duty to protect resident students); ... Eldredge v. Kamp Kachess Youth Serv., Inc., 90 Wash.2d 402, 408 (1978) (group child care facility's duty to control acts of delinquent children). ... See, e.g., ... McLeod v. Grant County School Dist. No. 128, 42 Wash.2d 316, 323-324 (1953) (duty to protect student from student third party at recess).

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that schools, youth organizations, and similar entities that assume responsibility for supervising children owe a duty to use reasonable care to protect those children from reasonably foreseeable harm arising from the conduct of other children.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion (a dissent in Mullins v. Pine Manor College) concerns a college’s duty to protect an adult student from criminal acts on campus, focusing on proximate causation and foreseeability of rape by an intruder or guest. It does not address schools, youth organizations, or entities supervising children, nor duties arising from the conduct of other children; the harm here was from an unidentified adult assailant. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for a duty to protect children from other children in supervised settings.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.

Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that schools, youth organizations, and similar entities that assume responsibility for supervising children owe a duty to use reasonable care to protect those children from reasonably foreseeable harm arising from the conduct of other children.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the duty a landowner owes to adult trespassers and expressly addresses only (1) imperiled trespassers whose presence is known and (2) certain foreseeable child trespassers under G.L. c. 231, § 85Q. It does not involve a school, youth organization, or any entity undertaking supervision of children, nor does it discuss a duty to protect children from the conduct of other children. The statements about child trespassers relate solely to landowner liability and statutory premises liability, not to supervisory duties in youth settings, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.relevant_excerpt:
We can say with confidence that landowners of ordinary prudence customarily exercise care for the safety of trespassers who are known to be in a position of peril, certain foreseeable child trespassers, and all lawful visitors.

General Laws c. 231, § 85Q, provides that a duty of reasonable care is owed to certain foreseeable child trespassers. This demonstrates the Legislature's recognition of a community consensus that landowners should exercise care for the safety of foreseeable child trespassers in certain circumstances.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that schools, youth organizations, and similar entities that assume responsibility for supervising children owe a duty to use reasonable care to protect those children from reasonably foreseeable harm arising from the conduct of other children.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes a duty of reasonable care in the context of a homeowner who allows guns to be stored on her property and gives unsupervised access to a mentally unstable, violent person. Its discussion of foreseeability and duty draws analogies to Pine Manor College (a student-safety case), but Jupin itself does not involve schools, youth organizations, or entities supervising children, nor does it articulate any rule specific to protecting children from harm by other children. Thus it does not establish the specific child-supervision duty described in the proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: We generally consider the latter three questions  whether a defendant exercised reasonable care, the extent of the damage caused, and whether the defendants breach and the damage were causally related  to be the special province of the jury. See Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 57-58 (1983) (Pine Manor). However, the existence of a duty is a question of law, and is thus an appropriate subject of summary judgment... We have recognized that [a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.

Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that schools, youth organizations, and similar entities that assume responsibility for supervising children owe a duty to use reasonable care to protect those children from reasonably foreseeable harm arising from the conduct of other children.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the duty of homeowner social hosts/landowners toward an adult social guest injured by fireworks brought and used by other guests. It analyzes landowner duties, exceptions for special relationships, and expressly declines to expand duties in the social host context. It does not address schools, youth organizations, child supervision, or duties arising from assuming responsibility for supervising children, and therefore cannot be authority for the proposition stated.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “As a general rule, a landowner does not owe a duty to take affirmative steps to protect against dangerous or unlawful acts of third persons. … An exception to this rule may be found where there is a special relationship between the defendant landowner and a plaintiff. … We have decided that such special relationships exist in several situations… We have never found such a special relationship between a homeowner and a social guest, which, absent other factors, would obligate the homeowner to protect guests on his premises from hazardous conduct on the part of other guests.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries; it is sufficient that Defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in bringing about those injuries.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses causation, but only in terms of proximate cause, foreseeability, intervening/superseding causes, and policy limits on liability. It does not articulate or apply the ‘substantial contributing factor’ standard, nor does it say that a defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of injury. Instead, the case turns on the conclusion that the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence was not the proximate cause at all, making this citation inapt for the claimed proposition.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.”

G.L. c. 231.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment and quality of life, pursuant to Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 231.

G.L. c. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: Plaintiff’s claims are brought within the applicable statute of limitations for negligence actions in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: To the extent applicable, Plaintiff invokes Mass. R. Civ. P. 8(a) and 9(g), and seeks all elements of damages available under Massachusetts law, including pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable rules, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
